We even had to ask the hostess to find our server and get our check after trying to wait patiently for 15 minutes.  - The fried green tomatoes came quickly and were decent. - There were no collard greens at 6:45 on  Saturday night, when the restaurant was largely empty. In summary... if "smoke" is in your name, bbq is in your description and brisket is a mainstay on the menu... you might want to find a new pit master if you want to stay open. fYbXGhH1DqrsgvJpIJIG4A.text: I want to be very careful about how to word this review. I will state at the outset that I very much want this restaurant (which has only been open for about 3 months) to do well. It has a nice backstory - native Pittsburgher with a passion for Southern cuisine reinvents a former Bloomfield landmark (Del's Restaurant - which I only remember from watching an episode of "Restaurant Impossible" a few years back). I know first hand that the head chef can cook. I attended an event several weeks ago on the South Side which the restaurant catered and all of the food was marvelous - delicious pulled pork, brisket, smoked salmon, collared greens, and mac n' cheese. It was very evident from the smile on the chef's face and the quality of the food that he loved to cook and took great pride his cuisine. My recent dining experience left me wondering whether that guy might have taken the night off. Or, more concerning, whether this restaurant is classic case of an owner and chef who know how to make good food but have no idea how to run a brick and mortar restaurant.  My evening started out strangely enough with the bartender unable to make one of the eight or so "signature" cocktails on the menu (Streetcar Named Desire) because they were out of peach schnapps (weird, but I was willing to give them a pass on this one). Things went quickly downhill from there. We dined rather late (8:30 PM), and were advised that the restaurant was out of several items (fried green tomatoes, brisket, and meatloaf) on what was an already fairly limited menu. Our appetizer came pretty quickly (brussel sprouts, which were just OK), but it then literally took 1 1/2 hours for our entrees to follow (the table next to us suffered the same fate, and actually cheered when their food arrived). One of the entrees (a simple grilled NY strip), was so overcooked that it was inedible, and one of our diners never received his entree (a hamburger - which, by the way, he knew in advance was going to be missing one of the key ingredients - the brisket!). My shrimp and grits should have been renamed "grits and shrimp" because it had precisely four shrimp in the dish.  Our poor waitress was very apologetic throughout the evening, and did her best to cover for what was obviously either an understaffed or inexperienced (perhaps inept?) kitchen. To make matters worse, the manager of the restaurant never came to our table to apologize for the train wreck that our evening had become. The coup de grace was when the bill came - the restaurant automatically added a 20% tip to the bill (which I paid, so as to not penalize the waitress who had nothing to do with our bad experience).  So, will I ever return? Definitely not until the owner and head chef have significantly more time to either work out the kinks or decide if perhaps they are better off going into the catering business.

ghuxWbBbjabAVvJRl9fUOw.text: How difficult is it to have enough green tomatoes on hand that you don't run out of fried green tomatoes only an hour after opening?  Ridiculous.  And for a place called Sugar and Smoke, there was nary a smoked item on the menu.  The brisket hash had fairly sizable chunks of brisket, but they were not as tender as they should have been, a sign that the brisket was pulled before it hit peak temp, and there was no smoke flavor whatsoever, no crust, and no smoke ring.  The brisket was an unappealing uniformly gray color, average tasting at best, and seemed to have been cooked sous vide or in a slow cooker rather than in a smoker, and lacking the tenderness you would expect.  Please, if you're going to mislead your patrons with Smoke in your name, then at least give us something smoked to choose from.  I don't think it's a stretch to assume that when you order a brisket hash at a place called Sugar and Smoke, the brisket is going to be of the smoked variety. Nope.  Guy next to us ordered the brisket hash also, but he didn't get the over easy eggs that came atop of ours.  Time to train the kitchen staff.    Brunch menu was very limited and pretty much entirely devoid of smoked meat.  I ordered the catfish which, while perfectly tender and juicy, came at the center of a lonely plate with a couple sprinkles of parsley and a few thin strands of pickled jalapeno.  A medium sized piece of cheap fish should come with some kind of small side, no?  Or is that asking too much? I was thankful I had added a side of mac and cheese, which was actually also quite tasty, creamy,  and nicely charred on top, but it should have been included, not an add on.  Bloody Mary was weak and devoid of horseradish, which of course, they didn't have.  Oddly, they tried to recommend a mango bloody mary to us.  We all looked at each other like, my god, who would do that to a bloody mary?  Even more weirdly, after we were done, the bartender came over and offered my wife a micro teaspoon sized taste of, not the mango bloody mary itself, but little bits of mango mixed with seasoning, which was presumably used to make the mango bloody marys.  Why offer us a taste of ingredients?  Wouldn't it make more sense to offer us a chance to sample the actual full concoction itself, rather that one of its component parts?  It didn't taste good and only served to reinforce our belief that mango would NOT be something that should EVER be added to a bloody mary.  But horseradish, yes, that should be fixed. Just really beyond weird.  Whoever is running this place seems to have very little experience in restaurant management.    This place needs work.  I'm not sure what they want to be.  Looks like they are trying to be high end with decor and pricing, but I would assume from the name they also want to be a barbeque joint?  Sure doesn't seem like they are trying too hard on the latter.  Where is the smoke???    Probably won't return.  Plenty of great places to eat in the burgh.

aGEM8AmXPpCspImOR8YI0w.text: Looking for a Saturday Brunch, and also wanting to have tried "Sugar & Smoke" since it opened, we ended up there for a lunch (though i got OJ and Coffee with my meal as it'd been a slow morning) we both loved yesterday. He highlighted a few menu items--the brussel sprouts, She Crab Bisque as well as the Brisket and Pulled Pork--as his favorites and gave us a few minutes to decide. FPm4s7cB-t61F8X7PWGG0w.text: We were really excited to try this place out as both the drink and dinner menus looked fantastic. Unfortunately our experience was less so.   On the plus: We arrived a little early for our 7:30 reservation, but we were kindly seated right away. We ordered old fashioneds to start and the charred brussel sprouts as an appetizer. Both the drinks and the brussels were great, although I thought the portion was small for an appetizer to be split between 2. You would certainly need to order multiples for more than 2 people. I had the shrimp and grits with cheddar, and they were excellent. We also ordered beignets for dessert. As with the appetizer, they were great, but a very small portion.   On the negative: Everything seemed to take an extremely long time (except for the appetizer, which came out very promptly). Our waitress was extremely kind and did apologize for the wait, although I got the impression that this is the current standard. I had ordered the collard greens as a side, but they were out of them--a disappoint for a self-proclaimed soul food restaurant, especially at a relatively early point in the evening. Opted for the cornbread instead; it was so-so. My fiance ordered the bone-in ribeye "rare to medium rare, more on the rare side." When it arrived, he cut into it and there was barely any pink. Given the wait time and the price point, this was probably our biggest upset with this restaurant.   It seems they have only been open a couple months, so I'm thinking they are still working out some kinks. Will give it another go in 6 months-a year once they have their footing. In the meantime, don't go there when you're too hungry since you'll have a bit of a wait, and don't order steak.

dT9QctSXuLPRGVaoCL86jg.text: This place has MAJOR service issues. Which is a bummer, because the food was actually really good...once we got it! We also had to request from the hostess, who wasn't present at first because she's apparently also the water server, for our waitress to come over, probably another 10 minutes after that, to take our drink orders. I don't think there was even anyone sitting at the bar.   The entrees didn't arrive until after 9:30 pm! We had two small appetizers and no soup/salad course in the meantime. SBj21rLAvt36R4Zq9nui7w.text: Okay, kiddos. We gave it some time and ordered different food to see what has changed. It's Friday and we didn't make reservations this time. No limited beer options this time. We ordered crafts and mulled over the menu. I love southern sides, but didn't think a couple alone (collard greens and mac and cheese) was enough. The gumbo and she crab soup were on my radar and asked Shay for her thoughts. No hesitation, she was all about the she crab, though noted it was on the spicy side. All goods. Hubs ordered the chicken and waffles. We shared brussel sprouts to start.  The brussel sprouts were solid. Lightly charred with cheese. I could have used some salt, but Hubs thought it was fine as is. My soup arrived, too. I made the mistake of not asking for it with dinner, so it got cold waiting for dinner to arrive. The soup itself was indeed spicy, more on the pepper flavor. It was more like bisque, with crab on top, so the flavors of the crab were less pronounced. Still solid and Hubs, not generally a fan of cream-based soup enjoyed it, too. My Mac and cheese was delightful, though I needed salt again. The collard greens were on point! It's cooked with some pork, so adds that southern flavor. Hub's chicken and waffle came with three pieces of wings! The waffle had a mild sweetness.   Glad to see the spot coming along. Definitely more of a neighborhood vibe and they've improved a bit!

6wkeJHcaS-h38DIjAODUSA.text: If I could give this place zero stars, I would. I absolutely hated everything about our meal and will never be back. Someone else had an issue with temperature of the shot of liquor they ordered, but we honestly couldn't stop laughing at how everyone's drink was either overpriced or terrible or both that I missed what his order was.   Our dinners took so long to come out. Probably 45-60 minutes waiting for our food. Everything we got was inconsistent. Some of it was good, some of it was bad. My meal was alright, but one member of our group ordered the Pittsburgh Hot Chicken... it was literally a chicken tender on a cafeteria bun with jar pickles on the side. On top of it all our waitress was either rude or busy or uninterested... she barely spoke to us, we asked for recommendations and she basically just said whatever we asked about was good (unhelpful, as proven by the Four Loko), and took about 10 years to bring our checks. Oh and my Four Loko, a beer, and two burgers (that we ate all of without being stuffed) ran us $80. So that was fun.

Da6h5pVZZLM3ktgl3Vx35g.text: So where do I start?  This is from a visit in the beginning of October 2018.  So I want to start off by saying, I know this is a new restaurant, so I will give them time to get the kinks out.  Unfortunately, I can't give them more than or less than 3 stars for that reason.   I was excited to try out the new restaurant,  so I went with my husband for a date night.  We were greeted at the door and immediately told that the regular chef was off, so they had a fill-in for the day, so the menu would be limited.    I figured the fill-in chef should be able to execute the dishes, so we stayed.   We enjoyed the ambience of the restaurant and the modern decor was very appealing.  We were escorted to our seats by the server and then warned by her that a party of 10 was coming soon, so we need to get our order in ASAP.  We reviewed the menu and I ordered the brisket and my husband ordered the steak, medium-well.  For the sides we requested mac & cheese and greens, but they ran out of greens, so I got corn muffins and he got mixed vegetables.  The waitress took our orders and then her party of  10 had come in.  She attended to them and when our food come out, that the last we heard from her in a while.  (At least 30 -40 minutes) We had to keep making hand gestures to get her to acknowledge us and come over.  Now the food: Brisket unfortunately was dry and crumbly, I feel like I got the shavings of the outside of the meat.  The mac and cheese was ok, I was hoping for baked mac, but It was stove top creamy similar to velveeta shells and cheese.  My husband's steak was medium-rare, instead of well.  I understand most people may eat rare, but it should be cooked as he requested.  He did say the vegetables were seasoned well and were delicious.  Overall, we were not fully satisfied with our visit, but I won't completely write them off.  This place can be great, I think I just need to give them more time (maybe 6 months to 1 yr) and try again when the real chef is there.

Bn3_gGwp7ZcP8LcxRkaCHw.text: I went to this place for a private party in the Blue Room and I have to say this place was amazing! From the decor to the hostesses, this restaurant surpassed any expectation of what it is to host at a fancy restaurant by treating their guest with respect, being attentive, and being about great home cooked food.   Ok for starters, let's talk about food,  The menu consisted of two proteins, one veggie, and a starch, as the following:  Collard greens - the greens were succulent! They were also flavorful and had meat (turkey meat) in it. This was prepared well enough for you to make you think a grandma from the south made this dish. Well done.   Macaroni and cheese - many restaurants don't do this justice and I can say for sure that this restaurant did it justice! It was so cheesy flavorful and well made. I can't say how using real cheese go a long way. Also, how delicious the seasoning is when it's done properly.  Salmon - this was prepared by smoking it but the juices were still there! There's nothing worst than badly prepared fish. So flavorful and juicy.   Smoked Chicken - this delicious chicken fell off the bones, man was it good. Can't go wrong with smoked seasoned well chicken. The reduction on the chicken was cooked in a way that you still tasted the juice in the chicken. Very well done.

G9SSYb8xPgBktI2v2-VeLw.text: You know I will never understand horrible reviews when it comes to a grand opening. I've read the negative ones about opening last night and all I can ask myself is, "what do people expect?" It's the first day for crying out loud, give the establishment a chance to work out the kinks. We went today for an early dinner; reservations at 4 pm. It wasn't overwhelmingly busy but there was a  steady flow of patrons. Also it's Steeler Sunday so you know... The decor and design are spot on. As soon as we walked in the door it felt new, better and so different than the previous place (Jabo's). There's a fantastic VIP room that's relaxing and reminiscent of a high-end jazz club. The owner Andrea and her daughter Morgan stopped by our table and chatted with us. Wonderful and lovely mother and daughter. Andrea is a smart business woman with a grand love of food. Serving a menu that offers a mixture of the finest southern delicacies, brisket and bbq.  My boyfriend and I shared a plate of fried green tomatoes that were so juicy with a flavorful and light breading cooked to perfection. My boyfriend had the gumbo that was packed with okra, rice, sausage and peppers. I had a taste of it and had trouble giving it back to him because it was simply fantastic! Hit all the right notes on my pallet. The Pittsburgh Hot Chicken Sandwich is huge!! More than big enough for two. Served on a lightly toasted brioche bun with a sauce that hits just the right level of heat. The chicken was fried Southern-style with a crisp breading that didn't taste greasy but instead exactly the way a good fried chicken should taste. We finished with dessert. We shared beignets sprinkled with powdered sugar and sides of chocolate sauce, Kentucky bourbon sauce and Chantilly cream.  Those beignets were a dream come True I tell you! Pittsburgh twist on a NOLA classic. The staff are friendly, on point and extremely knowledgeable.  Our server Sarah described item menus with intricate detail and took us on a tour of the VIP room. We  were even given a sample of the brisket which the chef preps with a coffee marinade for 12 hours. Not hard to figure out what we're ordering next time. As Bloomfield residents, we agree this is a welcome addition to our neighborhood!

bV9dpEiDfLgBACqn8aEpqw.text: Very nice people cooking and serving an expensive and disappointing experience. I can forgive the unflattering decor and inexperienced (slow, untrained, unavailable) service, but I can't really forgive the mediocre food that continues to plague this building.  Our $21 plate of brisket was served gray, contained mostly fat, and seemed to be pulled/chopped, not sliced. There wasn't any carbonation in our drinks from the tap. The "sugar and smoke" sauce tasted like ketchup. The sides were nice. I really enjoyed the coleslaw. I'm also not sure why a place like this doesn't service the sandwiches, which look to be the most appetizing and affordable options, beyond lunch.   It isn't worth itemizing the mistakes made on our bill or the slow service other than just suggesting that the staff could use some training and the space could use some branding. The menu could use some simplifying and I'm not interested in paying $50 for two people to eat uninspiring food that I could make better at home.

23sJwkg8laHBcShQ1S17Qg.text: The shrimp and grits were good (not great, but a solid good so I'd order again), the beignets were under cooked.  The hush puppies were tasty, and the pecan salad arrived sans pecans, but I guess the other waitress noticed and brought them in a small cup on the side.   However my real issue was with the speed of service. I'm good with my food being cooked to order, but not when it seems to include a trip to the fish market and supermarket for ingredients.   My very simple dinner was almost a 2 hour evolution!  I could even understand if I arrived during the dinner rush, however the dinner rush didn't start until an hour after I was seated.  My server was friendly and personable, however...2 hours?  The menu is limited (and they were out of two of their entrees (meatloaf and brisket which seemed to strange) so I'm again hard pressed to understand the delay.  The decor is nice and trendy, so if one is looking for a place to chill after work, with some ok eats, different from the usual fare, then this place fits that bill.  I wouldn't make a special trip there, but again when looking for something different in the burgh, it's on the list of places to try.    Oh, if by some chance the owners see my post, beyond what is mentioned, I'd suggest acoustic tiles.  The place gets really loud really quick because of the high ceilings.   I really wanted to rave about this place, but...

BlY6k0xnYZ3TVF8Gk-7mJg.text: My sister and I went to dinner at Sugar n Smoke last Friday and let me just say it was an excellent experience.  Everyone there I really nice. The staff appeared to enjoy working there.  Cocktails were good and served promptly.  We moved to a table and J was our server.  She was excellent, gave us suggestions, gave us time to order and always checked back with us.  We ordered the Hush Puppies and Fried Green Tomatoes as apps.  The Hush Puppies were pretty good and the Fried Green Tomatoes were a hit.  I'm not a FGT guy but I was all about them.  And the remoulade served with both items was tasty.  My sister ordered the Cajun Salmon and I the Shrimp n Grits, she also got a side of greens and mac n cheese.  The mac n cheese really wasn't fresh so we had to return it.  We sampled each others meals and were both very happy.  The salmon was awesome (wish I had ordered that) but my shrimp n grits was on point, and it was a nice sized serving.  I actually took 3/4 of it home and had a second meal the next day (J hooked me up with a little extra sauce.  Love her!!)  Oh, my nephew joined us later and they allowed us to move to a larger table.  He had the Shrimp Po Boy which he liked but wasn't expecting the shrimp to be corn meal dusted.  It was gone in no time so......lol  The maitre'd or manager (not sure of his position) was really accommodating. And even though they were getting busy for Friday dinner, we never felt rushed to finish and pay.  We had a great experience and can't wait to go back.  Almost forgot about the live keyboard player, I actually thought it was recorded music.  That really added a nice touch to the atmosphere.  Nice job with the menu Chef Chaz!!  Thanks Gary for being a great host and letting us peak at the downstairs lounge/party room.  They did a great job with the building.  Good luck Andrea, I wish you many years of success.  This was a nice add to the Pittsburgh restaurant scene.  See you all very soon!!
